Paper Title: Robust Hate Speech Detection in Social Media: A Cross-Dataset Empirical Evaluation
Dataset: 83,230 tweets from 13 source datasets (MHS, CMS,  HTPO, HateX, AHSD, HSHP, AYR, MMHS, HatE, HASOC, DEAP, LSC)
Method: BERT-base, RoBERTa-base (general-purpose models), BERTweet, SVM, and TimeLMs-21
Limitation: include reliance on existing datasets, limiting the generalizability of findings, and the use of base-sized language models.
Focus Area: automatic hate speech detection in online social media
Evaluation/ Accuracy: For single-class classification, TimeLMs performed best with an F1 score of 70.7, closely followed by BERTweet at 70.1. In multiclass classification, SVM achieved the highest F1 score of 81.9, while TimeLMs scored 71.6, BERTweet and RoBERTa had F1 scores of 70.9 and 69.5, and BERT achieved 66.9.

Paper Title: G-BERT: An Efficient Method for Identifying Hate Speech in Bengali Texts on Social Media
Dataset: Bengali Offensive Text from the Social Platform (BHSSP) dataset, comprising 20,000 posts, comments, and memes
Feature Extraction: N-gram features (unigrams to trigrams) and TF-IDF
Method: G-BERT, a hybrid model combining BERT and GRU, comparisons to other models like Bangla BERT, LSTM-BERT, AdaBoost-BERT, and L-BOOST.
Limitation: reliance on a relatively small dataset, absence of real-time assessment, and a narrow focus on hate speech detection
Focus Area: hate speech prevalence in Bengali texts on social media
Evaluation/ Accuracy: an accuracy rate of 95.56%, precision of 95.07%, recall of 93.63%, and the highest F1-score of 92.15%

Paper Title: Can natural language processing models extract and classify instances of interpersonal violence in mental healthcare electronic records: an applied evaluative study
Dataset: Clinical Records Interactive Search (CRIS) database. A dataset of 3,771 text extracts from the records of 2,832 patients.
Method: fine-tuned BioBERT
Limitation: instances of witnessing violence, temporality of violence mentions, hidden violence , generalizable to other settings or populations.
Focus Area: the occurrence of clinical references to violence in electronic health records
Evaluation/ Accuracy: Precision ranged from 89% to 98%, and recall ranged from 89% to 97% for different violence labels. 78% referred to physical violence, 61% referred to patients as perpetrators, and 33% referred to domestic violence.
